title: @Meddler: How much is Irelia likely to change when her rework hits?
body: It sounds like it's going to be a Poppy/Sion/Taric level full relaunch judging from what I've heard. Is the Q chaining at least staying? That's the only part of Irelia I need in my life :p

I just listed 14 casters and I'm not even looking at a set of 130 characters. I'm only looking at the set of melee ADs, which is the relevant set here and that makes the total 14 of 36 characters being pure or mostly pure casters or 38.9%. Only 10 of 36 are pure or close to pure AA champs, or 27.8%.

>Both Irelia's theme and her gameplay - a telekinetic blade wielding warrior - have strong leanings towards reworking her towards an AD-caster playstyle.

Maybe her theme leads this way (I'd make arguments to the contrary) but her gameplay certainly doesn't. In terms of gameplay she's an auto attack centric bruiser. Any rework which ignored this fact would be a terrible rework. Irelia has a fan base and the fan base she has expects her to play like Irelia, not like some randomly sown together caster.

>she can't ever be strong otherwise she spirals out of control and can facetank teams while insta-gibbing carries.

This is endemic of casters. If you look at casters like Renekton and Darius they will often fall into this pattern. Characters like Irelia and Jax tend not to unless there's an immensely broken item. Normally they will take several AAs to kill a target giving them and their team far more reaction time. 

Making Irelia a caster would make her more likely to fit this definition.

>I'd welcome a chance to see Irelia in her full bladed glory.

You don't even have a single game of Irelia on your OP.GG, why do you care?

Irelia's original design intentions really didn't have her set to be a heavy auto-attacker. It's largely through player input that it was discovered Irelia's kit made her into an absurdly powerful bruiser because of how overloaded her kit was at the time of her release. Moreover, you ignore my argument that her E and passive are poorly designed, and at the heart of her balance issues. It's all great and fine that Irelia uses auto-attacks to kill a target, but I'd argue the most fun aspects of her kit lie in her Q and R since they both exemplify high moments of gameplay and visceral displays of power. 

Idk why this needs to be said but you don't need to play a champion to a.) appreciate their design b.) understand problems/areas of improvement in their gameplay c.) wanting them to be more fun to play with and against d.) have a distinct gameplay identity

As an Irelia player, do you have ideas that could improve her instead of attacking someone who sincerely wishes for her to be _better?_

Is it the play style of a champ that defines a champ or the supposed theme of the champ that defines the champ.

Irelia has a play style that is by all means largely focused around sheen procs one after another and on hit . Those are the 2 main aspects of her play style and they do go fairly well together. 

Her passive is strong or yet weak depending on who you are facing since it can be either 40% CC reduction or none depending on the type of CC. It could be more interesting? Sure. But resistance to CC is a valuable tool if it can be used.

Jax and perhaps Lucian are only others that really falls in this same group of super high synergy with Trinity in both attack speed and sheen procs based on how they are usually played. With a few others like Xin, Fiora, Ezreal and Vi having potentially similar aspects but not having the short enough comedowns to make sheen procs nearly as much of a focus point or not nearly as much of a value put on attack speed for on hit.

 Fiora is a pretty good example of a champion that had an older kit that really didn't translate itself well into representing the playstyle of a fencer. She went from being a burst assassin highly reliant on quickly executing a combo, like Talon or Zed, to a melee hypercarry reliant on passive procs, AA resets and more sustained engages. I would agree that weaving Sheen procs is a very important part of Irelia's kit, and one of her best expression of player skill, and I think there's room to explore that if her kit relied on sustained telekinetic blade strikes. Truth by told I'm surprised there just isn't that much range in her kit to begin with - you'd think her R wouldn't be her only means of catching someone at a distance. 

As for the Tenacity, right now it's extremely binary - makes her impossible to deal with for champions reliant on cc and inconsequential against characters that don't. It's also a great deal of invisible power that doesn't have good readability in game. Conditional tenacity effects have had a lot of success (Alistair's and Olaf's ults, Eve and Garen's mobility) and I think her tenacity could be placed in her Hiten style skill in favour of giving her a more interesting and engaging passive.

Fiora had some rather bad issues mainly due to her old ult having no real counterplay, Riposte beign basically worthless against a number of situations and overall kit feeing like it failed to work together all that well.

Once her old ult was going there was nothing you could do to stop it or react to it. You could not have a janna ult or Ali Headbutt interrupt it.

In that Fiora needed some real changes to her kit and displayed issues that Riot considered important enough to move her rework up above a lot of older champs. Her new Kit is far healthier and addressed at least to some degree the issues she had. She is not perfect but far better. 

While Irelia might have some issues she is not displaying a lack of things you can do against her when she is even or a bit ahead. And Riot has been saying that they want to rework for for as long as I have been playing but clearly she is not that much of an issue given that other champs are constantly being put ahead of her.

>Irelia's original design intentions really didn't have her set to be a heavy auto-attacker.

She was always a primary auto attacker. If you look at what she's building in her [champion spotlight](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MFcsOX9xcIo) she has a Youmuu's and old Stark's, both of which were AS items. 

The game was fundamentally different when Irelia launched. AD casters weren't a thing, If you were an AD champ you were an auto attacker. Riot's only real foray into an AD caster up to that point was Pantheon, but he was just built Triforce>Ghostblade and played as a sort of soft AAer because there weren't better options. AD casters didn't really start being a thing until Riven's release, almost a year after Irelia's.

>It's all great and fine that Irelia uses auto-attacks to kill a target, but I'd argue the most fun aspects of her kit lie in her Q and R since they both exemplify high moments of gameplay and visceral displays of power.

I actually enjoy chase-down and auto attack styles far more than casters. For the most part I've found casters to have very bland "mash all the keys" styles. I don't know why this style is so prevalent amongst AD casters, it's not in mages but it seems like almost every AD caster plays this way. The only two exceptions I've found are Riv and GP, but I just don't enjoy GP's barrel chaining so that leaves Riven as the only AD caster I enjoy.

If you don't like AA centric champions that's fine, don't play them. Don't call for them to be changed into casters just because you don't enjoy them, because other people do.

>As an Irelia player, do you have ideas that could improve her instead of attacking someone who sincerely wishes for her to be better?

She doesn't need that much. All she'd actually need is passive changes. I'd agree that her passive probably isn't that great for the game, but nothing else on her kit is really bad, I actually think she has quite a good kit considering it's 5 and a half years old. It probably is the best kit from her time by quite a long way.

Most of Irelia's problems stem from her focus on auto attacks, though, particularly the lack of thematic resonance in her kit. If she's going to properly fulfil the telekinetic blade manipulator thing she's supposed to, she's going to be needing to do more interesting stuff than whacking people over the head with her blades repeatedly to output her damage. She should be using them in interesting and intelligent ways or she'll never do justice to the character she's supposed to be. She has a magic bond with her blades but if she is only using them to hit people straight out she may as well have any random sword.

Gameplay-wise pretty much every melee auto-attack bruiser is a design disaster and the only ones with real counterplay (Yasuo, Fiora) are despised by the community even more than the ball of stat alternatives (Irelia, Jax)  so I'm not sure it's advisable to try and make Irelia healthier than she is in the auto-attack bruiser design space. She'd be much, much more likely to succeed as an AD caster because that design is inherently less offensive.

Overall I think that Irelia as a character was never a good fit for the type of champion you want her to be. She'll always be at odds with her character if she's based on autos.

>Gameplay-wise pretty much every melee auto-attack bruiser is a design disaster and the only ones with real counterplay (Yasuo, Fiora) are despised by the community even more than the ball of stat alternatives (Irelia, Jax)

You're confusing counterplay and outplay potential.

Counterplay is the ability of your team to react appropriately to a character, it's often not individual and is normally strategical rather than mechanical. This is often stratagies such as picking on a weak early game or forcing a champ who can't splitpush into a splitpush scenario. Irelia and Jax have far more counterplay than Fiora and Yasuo.

Outplay potential is the ability to beat a champ with mechanical proficiency. This isn't actually counterplay as when the champion plays well you cannot outplay them. High outplay actually correlates to low counterplay, champs like Zed, Lee and Fiora actually don't have high counterplay because your only option to play against them is to be a better player, you can't pick on strategical weaknesses because these champs are just too well rounded and can play too many strategical roles.

I'd also argue Yas and especially Fiora aren't AA based. Yas's damage is as much from his Q as his AAs and Fiora is heavily reliant on her Q. I'd consider them both to be hybrid AA/Casters.

>She'd be much, much more likely to succeed as an AD caster because that design is inherently less offensive.

Is it? Last I checked people often complain about champs like Riven, Lee Sin, Renekton, GP and Darius when they're strong. All of these champs are more casters than AAers.

>Overall I think that Irelia as a character was never a good fit for the type of champion you want her to be. She'll always be at odds with her character if she's based on autos.

It's better for Irelia to be at odds with her theme than at odds with her player base. The simple fact is that Irelia players enjoy her as an auto attack based bruiser, you can't just ignore that when suggesting rework ideas.

You're a Sona main so I'll put this in a way you can understand. It's kind of like if the community started saying Sona should be balanced around being a midlaner. From a mechanical standpoint it makes sense, Sona's current kit is closer to a strong fit for mid than support, if her Q had an AOE splash ala Karma so she could wave control she'd be a pretty good mid and they'd be reasons to pick her which are currently somewhat lacking.

It's also a complete bastardisation of what Sona should be. In my case I'm bastardising Sona from a thematical standpoint while being consistent in a mechanical standpoint (she still plays the exact same), you're bastardising Irelia from mechanical standpoint (she plays completely differently) whilst being fair from a thematical standpoint. Both of these are terrible for the players of the champ.

Riot's main issues with her they discussed about a year or two ago.  Namely that she's themed around being a magical swordswoman with telekinetic spirit blades but she just runs up to people and stabs them.  Her lore of having floating blades is totally superfluous. The only part of her kit that even deals with unorthodox swordsmanship in the least is her blade-toss ult.  They were talking about stuff like having psychokinetic control and positioning of her swords being the crux of her character instead of an afterthought.  Basically making her more of a mid-range zone control manipulation type deal in the style of an AD Syndra.  Instead of "beefy lady what runs into fight and hits peoples with sword".

>They were talking about stuff like having psychokinetic control and positioning of her swords being the crux of her character instead of an afterthought.

I really hope riot doesn't do this.  I mean I don't think shen's new blade ability is that popular, or it wasn't the last time I checked, and I don't think irelia players want to play shen or azir.  We have shen and azir.  Her being a control champ at this point would just feel wrong.  

Plus at this point, riot's writers can and love to ~~screw up~~ ~~derpize~~ ~~completely miss the point and spirit of~~  retcon any champ they want to, when they want to.  Since I value her gameplay more than I value 3-5 paragraphs that were written to the standard of a fighting game.  Plus when you consider riot has a history of flushing lore down the crapper, lore isn't something I'd want to focus a redesign around.

She's still going to be melee but have a lot of ranged stuff on her kit ala Yorick, Ekko, Zed, and Gangplank.  I think they said they were thinking about keeping Bladesurge and her Transcendent Blades (but that it would probably not be remain an Ult and have an ammo system) and scrapping her other abilities and her passive in favor of ranged zone control spells.  So they're probably going to be forcing her out of the jungle and squarely into either mid or top.  They specifically noted her sustain + cc resistance as particularly bad ideas that were going to be removed. Of course, this was just what a few devs were spitballing over a year ago.
